Glycerol acetalization to solketal is a promising method of increasing the additional value of glycerol, which is a by-product in biodiesel industry. In this work, a series of mesoporous x-MoO3-ZrO2 (x = Mo/Zr) solid acid catalysts with controllable Mo contents were designed and synthesized for the acetalization of glycerol. As important influence factors of solid acid catalysts, the mesoporous structure and existential state of Mo species were systematically investigated. Results show that Mo species were introduced as planned and existed in a homogeneously dispersed state in MoO3-ZrO2 materials. The acidic properties of MoO3-ZrO2 were explored through NH3-TPD and pyridine-chemisorbed FT-IR spectroscopy, and the formation of Brønsted and Lewis acid sites was confirmed by density functional theory calculations. Given their excellent acidity, MoO3-ZrO2 catalysts were employed for the acetal reaction of glycerol. Among the tested catalysts, the 20 %-MoO3-ZrO2 catalyst exhibited the optimal catalytic performance and reusability, achieving a conversion of 89 % for glycerol and a selectivity of 97 % for solketal. Consequently, MoO3-ZrO2 is a green solid acid catalyst with promising applications in solvent-free solketal production from glycerol. Introduction In recent years, biodiesel has attracted great attention as a new clean energy ascribing to its nontoxic, harmless, and renewable advantages [1]. In general, biodiesel is obtained by the transesterification between vegetable oils and methanol, resulting in the generation of a substantial amount of glycerol as a by-product [2]. Therefore, the effective utilization of glycerol has become a worthy research subject [3–5]. Numerous studies have concentrated on the transformation of glycerol to high value-added chemicals, such as ketalization [6], reformation [7], dehydration [8], and oxidation [9]. Among them, the acetalization reaction of glycerol with carbonyl compounds has attracted great attention due to its potential to produce oxygen-containing compounds, such as spices, surfactants, and low toxicity bio-based solvents [10,11]. There are many methods for acetalization of glycerol and carbonyl compounds, such as thermal catalysis [12,13], photocatalysis [14], and microwave-assisted conversion [15]. Among them, the solketal product, formed by direct acetalization of glycerol and acetone (Scheme 1 ), is of particular importance and can also be used as a fuel additive for biodiesel [16]. The acetal reaction of glycerol and acetone can be promoted by a homogeneous or heterogeneous acid catalyst. The utilization of homogeneous catalysts presents certain challenges, including product separation, equipment corrosion, and environmental pollution [13,17]. Therefore, heterogeneous catalysts, such as heteropoly acid [18], zeolite [19], metal oxide [20], sulfates [21], and ionic liquids [22], have become the preferred catalysts in acetal reaction. In the domain of solid acid catalysts, metal oxide WOx-ZrO2 and MoOx-ZrO2 have attracted extensive attention as solid acid catalysts because of their excellent activity and stability. Therefore, the construction of highly efficient MoOx-ZrO2 solid acid catalysts for the acetal reaction of glycerol and the exploration of the formation of Brønsted and Lewis acid sites are of great significance [23,24]. Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) are a novel kind of porous material with well-defined structures, large surface areas, and regular pore channels. These frameworks have been widely investigated in adsorption and gas storage/separation [25,26], energy storage [27], drug delivery [28,29], and heterogeneous catalysis [30,31]. Among them, the UiO family (zirconium-based MOFs) with excellent chemical, thermal, and mechanical properties has drawn extensive attentions [32,33]. UiO-66 material, which has [Zr6O4(OH)4]12+ bricks and terephthalate linkers, is regarded as the parent of UiO members [34] and has the potential to be utilized for synthesizing ZrO2-based solid acid catalysts. In this study, the incorporation of Mo into the UiO-66 framework through the one-pot hydrothermal method was explored, and a MoO3-ZrO2 solid acid catalyst with excellent performance was produced and applied in the acetalization of acetone and glycerol. The effects of the Mo doping amount and calcination temperature on the mesoporous structure and existence of Mo species in the catalyst were investigated in detailed. The Brønsted and Lewis acid sites of MoO3-ZrO2 were studied and confirmed by experiments and theoretical calculations. Finally, the MoO3-ZrO2 solid acid catalysts were employed in the acetal reaction of glycerol with acetone. The influence factors of acetalization, such as the reaction temperature, the reaction time, the catalyst mass and the molar ratio, were studied. To verify the universality of MoO3-ZrO2 solid acid catalyst, different substrates were researched in the acetalization of glycerol. In addition, reusability tests were carried out to confirm the stability of catalyst. This work is expected to incentivize the progress of highly efficient solid acid catalysts for glycerol acetalization. Experimental section Materials Zirconium oxychloride octahydrate (ZrOCl2·8H2O, Aladdin Chemistry Co. Ltd), ammonium molybdate tetrahydrate ((NH4)6Mo7O24·4H2O, Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co. Ltd), N, N-dimethylformamide (DMF, Aladdin Chemistry Co. Ltd), 1,4-dicarboxybenzene (H2BDC, Aladdin Chemistry Co. Ltd), methanol (CH3OH, Aladdin Chemistry Co. Ltd), and ultrapure water (18.2 mΩ) were used as received without further purification. Preparation of MoO3-ZrO2 materials The preparation process of the MoO3-ZrO2 material is displayed in Scheme 2 . Mo-doped UiO-66 (Mo-UiO-66) materials with controllable Mo contents were fabricated through the one-pot hydrothermal method. First, 6 mmol of ZrOCl2·8H2O and 6 mmol of H2BDC were dissolved in 62 mL of DMF. Then, a predefined amount of (NH4)6Mo7O24·4H2O was introduced. After the complete dissolution, the solution was placed in a Teflon autoclave at 120 °C for 24 h of heat treatment. After cooling to room temperature, the precipitates were treated by extraction and percolation method. The separated materials were then washed three times by DMF and CH3OH. Finally, the cleaned material was dried in an oven at 130 °C. After 4 h of thermal treatment at 700 °C in a muffle furnace, the x-MoO3-ZrO2 was obtained, where x (x = 0, 5 %, 10 %, 20 %, and 30 %) is the molar ratio of Mo/Zr. Characterization of catalysts The Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) analysis was conducted using a Bruker D8 Advance diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation. The scan range spanned from 10.0° to 80.0° at 10° min−1. Raman spectra were acquired using a Laboram 010 Confocal Raman System (Horiba Jobin Yvon, France) with a 632 nm He-Ne laser. The wavelength range of the system extended from 100 cm−1 to 1200 cm−1. N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms were achieved using a 3-Flex physical adsorption apparatus. The specific surface area was determined through the Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) method. The pore volume was obtained from the N2 adsorption at a relative pressure of 0.99 and the pore size distribution (PSD) curve was achieved from the NLDFT analysis of the adsorption branch of the adsorption curve. A FEI TECNAI G2 F20 high-resolution transmission electron microscopy with an acceleration voltage of 200 kV was used to obtain transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images, HRTEM images, energy-dispersive X-ray energy spectra (EDS), element mapping, and selected area electron diffraction (SAED) patterns. A UV-2450 UV–Vis spectrophotometer was utilized to measure the absorption spectrum of the sample with a range of 200–800 nm. A Chembet PULSAR TPR/TPD chemisorption apparatus was utilized to perform temperature programmed reduction (TPR) on catalytic materials. The reduction was carried out using a mixture of H2 N2 gas (5 mol% H2–95 mol% N2) as the reducing agent (20 mL min−1) from 20 °C to 950 °C (10 °C min−1). A Thermo Scientific K-Alpha+ X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) instrument was used to irradiate Al Kα rays, and the obtained binding energy was calibrated using the C1s binding energy (284.8 eV). These curves were fitted with the Avantage software. The NH3-TPD test was performed using the Chembet PULSAR TPR/TPD chemisorption apparatus. The samples were preprocessed at 500 °C for 1 h, adsorbed NH3 for 30 min at room temperature, purged in Ar for 2 h, and finally heated to 800 °C for NH3 desorption. Pyridine-IR spectra were obtained at various desorption temperatures on a PE Frontier FT-IR spectrometer. The samples were pretreated at 350 °C for 2 h, adsorbed in pyridine vapor at 100 °C for 30 s, and then heated to 150 °C, 250 °C, and 350 °C for vacuum desorption for 10 min to remove the physisorbed pyridine. Subsequently, the infrared spectral signals were recorded. DFT calculations All the first-principles calculations presented here were performed using the DMol3 package [35], implemented in Materials Studio 2019, with Perdew-Burke-Ernzerhof generalized gradient approximation [36] and the Tkatchenko-Scheffler van der Waals correction method [37,38]. The geometries were relaxed using a double numerical-polarized basis set, and the convergence criterion of the maximum force was set to 2 × 10−3 Hartree/Å. To construct the computational model, the primitive cells of both tetragonal ZrO2 (t-ZrO2) and monoclinic ZrO2 (m-ZrO2) were optimized using 5 × 5 × 5 Monkhorst-Pack mesh k-points. Subsequently, t-ZrO2 (101) and m-ZrO2 (−111) slabs were constructed from the respective lattice structures, each comprising of 48 Zr atoms and 96 O atoms. The slabs were given a vacuum of 20 Å in the z direction, while the bottom layers of the ZrO2 were constrained to the positions of their bulk structures. Lastly, H2O molecules were adsorbed onto the slabs to simulate the Brønsted acid sites, and 3 Mo atoms and 9 O atoms were coated on the t-ZrO2 to simulate the incorporated Mo species. Catalytic reaction The acetalization reaction between glycerol and acetone was performed in a round-bottomed flask equipped with a reflux condenser in an oil bath. Initially, 0.03 g of solid acid catalyst, 1 g of glycerol, and 5 g of acetone (molar of glycerol: molar of acetone = 1:8) were introduced to the reactor. Thereafter, the mixture was reacted at 50 °C for 10 min under stirring condition. After the reaction, the mixture was separated and taken for gas chromatography (GC) to perform quantitative analysis. Furthermore, the reusability of the MoO3-ZrO2 catalyst was evaluated. After each reaction, the MoO3-ZrO2 catalyst was recovered from the liquid phase, filtered and cleaned with ethanol, and then treated at 700 °C for 2 h to remove the organic substances adsorbed on the catalyst. The treated catalyst was then evaluated for five cycles. In addition, the reaction products were detected through Shimadzu GC-2010Plus gas chromatography with a Rtx Wax column (50 m × 0.53 mm × 1 μm) and a hydrogen flame ionization detector. The quantity of five-membered ring and six-membered ring products was quantified by standard curve method. The catalytic performance (conversion of glycerol and selectivity of solketal) was evaluated using the following equation: (1) Yield of solketal ( mol % ) = mole of solketal detected mole of solketal theoretical × 100 mol % (2) Selectivity of solketal ( mol % ) = Yield of solketal Yield of solketal + Yiled of acetal × 100 mol % (3) Conversion of glycerol ( mol % ) = Yield of solketal Selectivity of solketal × 100 mol % Results and discussion Textural properties of materials The structure of MoO3-ZrO2 materials with varying Mo contents was investigated by XRD, Raman, and N2-physisorption techniques. As shown in the XRD patterns (Fig. 1 a), the 0 %-MoO3-ZrO2 material exhibits significant diffraction peaks at 24.1°, 28.2°, 31.5°, and 40.7°, which corresponds to the (011), (−111), (111), and (−211) planes of m-ZrO2 (JCPDS card no. 83–0944), indicating the existence of m-ZrO2. Furthermore, weak peaks at 30.2°, 35.2°, 50.3°, and 60.2°, which respectively correspond to the (101), (110), (112), and (211) crystal planes of t-ZrO2 (JCPDS card no. 80–0784), are detected, proving the existence of t-ZrO2. The introduction of Mo species leads to the gradual enhancement of clear diffraction peaks of t-ZrO2, suggesting that the presence of Mo species hinders the transition of the material skeleton from t-ZrO2 to m-ZrO2 during high-temperature treatment. When the Mo/Zr ratio reaches 20 %, the material fully adopts a tetragonal structure, indicating that the presence of Mo species enhances the stability of the t-ZrO2 structure. Additionally, no diffraction peak associated with MoO3 is observed, even at the Mo species content of 30 %. This phenomenon can be attributed to the high dispersion of MoO3 in the skeleton of material and the lack of crystallization of Mo species. To further confirm the structure of MoO3-ZrO2 materials, the Raman spectra were analyzed and are presented in Fig. 1b. As for the 0 %-MoO3-ZrO2 material, the dominant crystal phase is m-ZrO2, with characteristic peaks appearing at 179 cm−1, 190 cm−1, 476 cm−1, and 578 cm−1 [39]. However, the characteristic peaks of t-ZrO2 at 148 cm−1, 270 cm−1, 313 cm−1, and 645 cm−1 are increased with the enhancement of Mo content [40], which is consistent with the conclusion of XRD characterization, further indicating that the presence of Mo is conducive to the stability of t-ZrO2 structure. The textural properties of MoO3-ZrO2 materials were investigated using the N2 adsorption-desorption isotherm. As displayed in Fig. 1c, the hysteresis loop of the material without Mo doping (0 %-MoO3-ZrO2) is the type between H1 and H2, proving the absence of a mesoporous structure. Meanwhile, the introduction of Mo species leads to the formation of a type IV isotherm with a H1 hysteresis loop, which is symbolic of mesoporous structure in the P/P0 range of 0.4–0.7. Furthermore, Fig. 1d reveals that these Mo-doped materials exhibit a distinct PSD of approximately 4 nm, confirming the successful preservation of mesoporous structure. Table 1 displays the textural properties of MoO3-ZrO2 materials. As the increasing of Mo content, the specific surface area enhances from 11.9 m2 g −1 for 0 %-MoO3-ZrO2 to 78.1 m2 g −1 for 30 %-MoO3-ZrO2. Additionally, the pore size of the material changes little with the enhancement of Mo content. The TEM images, HRTEM images, SAED patterns, and element mapping images of MoO3-ZrO2 with varying amounts of Mo are presented in Fig. 2 . The TEM image of 0 %-MoO3-ZrO2 material (Fig. 2a1), clearly shows that the agglomerated particles exhibit a significantly large size, with disordered stacking and without a mesoporous structure. However, the material displays a distinct stacked mesoporous structure (Figs. 2b1, 2c1, 2d1, and 2e1) with the introduction of Mo element (5 %−30 %), which are consistent with the results of PSD analysis. Furthermore, the HRTEM images (Figs. 2a2 and 2a3) of 0 %-MoO3-ZrO2 indicate that the material exhibits lattice spacing values of 0.28 nm and 0.26 nm, corresponding to the (111) and (002) lattice planes of m-ZrO2, respectively. Moreover, detailed analysis of the SAED pattern of material (Fig. 2a4) indicates the presence of diffraction rings that perfectly align with the crystallographic planes of m-ZrO2 when the Mo doping concentration is 0 %, suggesting that the material adopts the crystal structure of m-ZrO2. In the case of Mo doping concentrations of 5 % (Figs. 2b2 and 2b3) and 10 % (Fig. 2c2 and 2c3), lattice planes with a spacing of 0.31 nm are detected in both materials, according to the (−111) lattice planes of m-ZrO2. Additionally, lattice plane spacings of 0.29 nm and 0.18 nm are observed, matching the (101) and (112) lattice planes of t-ZrO2, respectively. These results indicate the coexistence of t-ZrO2 and m-ZrO2 crystal structures in 5 %-MoO3-ZrO2 and 10 %-MoO3-ZrO2 materials. These SAED patterns of m-ZrO2 and t-ZrO2 (Fig. 2b4 and 2c4) also exhibit diffraction rings, which are aligned with their respective crystallographic planes, and consistent with these observations from HRTEM images. As the increasing of Mo doping concentration to 20 % (Fig. 2d2 and 2d3) and 30 % (Fig. 2e2 and 2e3), the lattice spacings of these two materials are 0.29 nm and 0.25 nm, respectively, corresponding to the (101) and (110) lattice planes of t-ZrO2. Additionally, these SAED patterns (Fig. 2d4 and 2e4) show only diffraction rings corresponding to t-ZrO2. These results indicate the complete transformation of the material into the t-ZrO2 crystal structure for 20 %-MoO3-ZrO2 and 30 %-MoO3-ZrO2 materials, which is consistent with the XRD and Raman results. Finally, the element mapping reveals (Fig. 2a5–2e5) that Mo species are introduced as planned and uniformly exists in the framework of MoO3-ZrO2 materials. Existing states of Mo species and chemical bonds The states of Mo and chemical bonds in MoO3-ZrO2 materials were investigated through Raman, UV, H2-TPR, and XPS characterizations. The Raman spectra (Fig. 3 a) show no significant peak at 700–1100 cm−1 for 0 %-MoO3-ZrO2. However, as the Mo content increases from 5 % to 30 %, three bands appear at approximately 810 cm−1, 950 cm−1, and 980 cm−1, and the peak intensity increases with the Mo content. The band at 850 cm−1 is attributed to the vibration of oligomeric species (Mo-O-Mo), while the bands at 950 cm−1 and 980 cm−1 are attributed to isolated Mo species [41]. The results show that Mo exists in the skeleton in a highly dispersed state, which is in accord with the XRD and element mapping conclusion. The UV–Vis spectrum of the MoO3-ZrO2 material is presented in Fig. 3b. For the 0 %-MoO3-ZrO2 material, only one peak ascribing to the Zr-O bond is detected at 228 nm [42]. As the introducing of Mo species, a distinct broad peak appears at around 310 nm, attributing to the oxygen-metal charge transfer transition between Mo6+ (Mo=O) and Zr4+ (Zr-O-Zr) [43]. Moreover, the UV peak at approximately 310 nm increases with the content of Mo species from 5 % to 30 %, indicating the increase of dispersed Mo species. In addition, the diffuse reflection UV–Vis spectra of (5 %−30 %)-MoO3-ZrO2 materials are shown in Fig. S1. The absorption edge energy (AE) provides an accurate description of the electronic properties of metal oxides, because it corresponds to the energy required for electrons to transfer from the oxygen of the oxide to the metal site [44,45]. The AE value of MoO3-ZrO2 material enhances gradually with the increase of Mo content. These results are also consistent with the trends observed for dispersed MoOx [44,46]. The status of the introduced Mo species was analyzed using H2-TPR patterns. As displayed in Fig. 3c, no significant peak is detected at 100–900 °C for the 0 %-MoO3-ZrO2 material, indicating the absence of reducible species in the ZrO2. Upon the introduction of Mo species, the reduction peaks of the four materials appear at approximately 430 °C, which can be attributed to the reduction of dispersed poly-molybdate species [47]. Additionally, a significant reduction peak is detected at approximately 820 °C, corresponding to the decrease of molybdate from Mo6+ to Mo4+ [48]. With the augment of the content of Mo, the intensities of reduction peaks increase. These results demonstrate that Mo species have been successfully incorporated into the material skeleton as designed. XPS test (Figs.3d and S2) was utilized to verify the composition of the sample and the valence states of Zr and Mo species. The Zr 3d5/2 and Zr 3d3/2 peak at 184.8 eV and 182.4 eV are observed, respectively (Fig. S2b). These results indicate that Zr exists as a + 4 valence state. Furthermore, the Mo 3d (Fig. 3d) signal appears in two different binding energies. The signals at 235.9 eV and 232.8 eV are assigned to 3d5/2 and 3d3/2 of Mo6+, further proving the results of Raman and UV–vis. As for the O 1 s signal (Fig. S2c), the signal peak generated by the Zr-O and Mo-O bonds is detected at 530.2 eV. Acidic characteristics The acidity of MoO3-ZrO2 materials was analyzed using NH3-TPD patterns. As displayed in Fig. 4 a, no desorption peak is observed in the 0 %-MoO3-ZrO2 material, indicating the absence of acidic sites. Conversely, the (5 %−30 %)-MoO3-ZrO2 materials exhibit an obvious desorption peak at the desorption temperature of 100 °C to 300 °C. The intensity of this peak demonstrates an upward trend as the Mo content increases, indicating an enhancement in the acidity of the materials. Moreover, the acid types of MoO3-ZrO2 materials with different Mo contents were studied using the pyridine-IR spectra. In Fig. 4b, the bands at 1540 cm−1 or 1450 cm−1 imply the presence of both Brønsted and Lewis acid sites in MoO3-ZrO2 materials. In addition, the infrared pyridine peak intensity of MoO3-ZrO2 materials gradually increases, especially for 20 %-MoO3-ZrO2 and 30 %-MoO3 ZrO2 materials, where strong Lewis acid peaks appear at 1596 cm−1 and 1446 cm−1. Moreover, the pyridine-IR spectra achieved after the treatment at 250 °C and 350 °C were used to study the strength of acid sites in MoO3-ZrO2 (Fig. S3). The Brønsted and Lewis acid sites can also be found even after treating at 250 °C. These results indicate that excellent Brønsted and Lewis acid sites exist in the MoO3-ZrO2 material. Given that Mo-doped t-ZrO2 exhibited both Brønsted and Lewis acidity and its promising catalytic performance for the acetal reaction, we were inspired to investigate this bimetallic oxide material using DFT calculations. The results of our calculations, which are presented in Table 2 , demonstrate that the lattice parameters and bond lengths of t-ZrO2 are consistent with the experimental and previous theoretical values, confirming that the employed model is capable of describing the t-ZrO2 structures. As illustrated in Fig. S4, the Zr atom is coordinated to eight O atoms in t-ZrO2, four of which are distant and four of which are close. This differentiation enables the categorization of unsaturated Zr atoms on the surface into two distinct groups: those lacking a long Zr-O bond and those lacking a short Zr-O bond. The tendency of surface energies of low index surfaces indicates that the (101) plane, identified by Piskorz [50] and Labat [51], exhibits the highest stability. The optimal structure of the H2O molecule adsorption is depicted in Figs. S5 and S6, exhibiting an adsorption energy of −1.83 eV and a Zr-O bond length of 2.01 Å. Furthermore, the coordination between O and Zr atoms is also modified. The dissociation of the water molecule results in a modification of the structure of the (101) surface, and the acidity of the active sites. The detached H atom is bonded to the adjacent O atom, resulting in an OH distance of 1.00 Å, while the OH bond length of the dissociated hydroxyl group is 0.99 Å. In order to assess the effect of the introduction of Mo on the acidity of the catalytic structure, we also constructed pure m-ZrO2 (−111) and MoO3 adsorbed t-ZrO2 (101) slabs both with H2O coating, based on the methodology established by Wachs [23]. Theoretical calculations have demonstrated that the Brønsted and Lewis acidity of this structure can be characterized by adsorbed probe molecules [23,49]. In order to analyze the acid sites and the catalytic performance, acetone was selected as the probe molecule, due to its involvement in the acetalization reaction. Acetone can be adsorbed on either dissociated hydroxyl H atoms (Fig. 5 a, 5b and 5c) or surface-unsaturated Zr atoms (Fig. 5d,–5f), with the latter exhibiting a more negative adsorption energy in each model, indicating the higher acidity of the Lewis acidic site, which can be utilized to activate the ketone. Besides, the adsorption energies and atomic charges also indicate that the Lewis acidity increases in the following order: pure m-ZrO2, pure t-ZrO2, and Mo-doped t-ZrO2, with the last showing the most significant improvement. Likewise, the Brønsted acidity follows a similar pattern. These findings imply a remarkable enhancement in the catalytic activity with Mo introduction which can be further confirmed in the subsequent experiment. Catalytic performance The experimental data and theoretical calculations reveal that MoO3-ZrO2 catalytic materials possess excellent acid sites, making them suitable for catalyzing the acetalization reaction between glycerol and acetone. The possible reaction mechanism (Scheme 3 ) is composed of five steps: (I) activation of the ketone through the acid sites of the catalyst, (II) coordinating the ketone with glycerol, (III) proton transfer to form a hemiketal, (IV) proton transfer and dehydration, and (V) coordinating another hydroxyl group to the tertiary carbon center, thus forming the ketal and completing the cycle. According to theoretical calculations, when acetone is adsorbed onto the active site in Step I, electrons are transferred from the catalyst to acetone, resulting in an increased carbon oxygen bond distance of acetone, thereby indicating that acetone is activated. Besides, the glycerol molecule contains multiple hydroxyl groups, which allows for the formation of either a five- or six-membered ring product in Step V [52]. To explore the acetalization reaction between acetone and glycerol, various factors of the reaction's performance, such as the Mo content, the reaction temperature, the reaction time, the catalyst dosage, and the reactant molar ratio were discussed. First, the effect of different Mo contents on the catalytic performance was specifically investigated (Fig. 6 a). The catalytic performance of 0 %-MoO3-ZrO2 is poor with little catalytic activity. As the enhancement of Mo species, the conversion of glycerol is gradually increased, indicating that the highly dispersed Mo on the ZrO2 framework is the active site of acetalization reaction. The catalyst with a 20 % Mo doping content (20 %-MoO3-ZrO2) exhibits the highest activity, reaching a conversion of 89 % and a selectivity of 97 % for glycerol. In addition, the catalytic performance of MoO3-ZrO2 calcined at 600 °C and 800 °C for the acetalization reaction of glycerol and acetone is shown in Fig. S7. A comparative study reveals that the catalytic performance of the catalyst calcined at 600 °C and 800 °C is lower than that calcine at 700 °C. Moreover, the catalytic performance of 20 %-MoO3-ZrO2 catalyst was further studied at different temperatures (30 °C, 40 °C, 50 °C, 60 °C, and 70 °C) (Fig. 6b). The conversion of glycerol increases gradually until it reaches 88 % at 50 °C. However, the conversion of glycerol changes slightly with the further increase in temperature, thus making 50 °C the optimal reaction temperature for this system. Moreover, the impact of various reaction conditions (reaction time, filtration test, catalyst mass, and the ratio of glycerol to acetone reactants) on the catalytic reaction were also investigated. The data presented in Fig. 6c demonstrates a positive correlation between reaction time and solketal yield. Notably, the solketal yield reaches 84 % when the reaction time is 10 min. Further extension of the reaction time does not significantly increase the yield. These findings indicate that the MoO3-ZrO2 catalyst exhibits rapid activity in the reaction, with the optimal reaction time being 10 min. For confirming the heterogeneity of solid acid catalyst, a filtration experiment was conducted, in which the catalyst was leached out of the reaction medium after 2 min of reaction. Subsequently, the reaction was carried out for an additional hour in the absence of catalyst. However, the conversion and selectivity remain unchanged, indicating that there is no active site in the reaction system and no active component of the catalyst is transferred to the solution. Therefore, the MoO3-ZrO2 catalyst is a heterogeneous catalyst with remarkable performance. The effect of catalyst dosage on the conversion of glycerol and selectivity of solketal was studied by changing catalyst mass (Fig. 6d). No product is detected in the absence of the catalyst, and the catalytic performance gradually improves with the increasing catalyst dosage from 0.01 g to 0.03 g. However, when the catalyst dosage further increases to 0.04 g, the glycerol conversion shows no significant increase. Therefore, 0.03 g of catalyst is the suitable amount for this reaction system, because it provides sufficient catalytic active sites. The molar ratio of acetone to glycerol is a key factor in determining catalytic performance. The results in Fig. 6e show that the conversion of glycerol is greatly enhanced, reaching 89 % when the ratio of acetone to glycerol increases from 2:1 to 8:1. Further increasing the ratio beyond 10:1, no significant improvement in catalytic performance is observed, indicating that 8:1 is the optimal acetone to glycerol molar ratio. In addition, compared with the previously reported catalysts (Table S1), it was found that some catalysts involved in the reaction had longer reaction time, and even some catalysts (WO3-SnO2, Fe/Al-SBA-15, and MoO3-SnO2) were not efficient in terms of conversion and market price. However, the MoO3-ZrO2 catalyst prepared in this work only needs a less amount, a lower reaction temperature, and a shorter reaction time to show excellent catalytic performance in the acetal reaction of glycerol and acetone. The 20 %-MoO3-ZrO2 catalyst was recycled to assess its cyclic performance under the most favorable conditions, including 10 min of reaction time, 0.03 g of catalyst and 8:1 acetone to glycerol ratio. As shown in Fig. 6f, the activity of the catalyst remains nearly unchanged after five cycles, suggesting that this catalyst is highly reliable and thus a promising solid acid catalyst for the acetal reaction of glycerol and acetone. The 20 %-MoO3-ZrO2 catalyst was assessed in the acetalization reaction of glycerol with various aldehydes and ketones, such as furfural, 4-methylfurfural, cyclopentanone, cyclohexanone, 4-methylcyclohexanone, benzaldehyde, 4-chlorobenzaldehyde, 4-methylbenzaldehyde, and 1-acetophenone, at 50 °C, with 0.03 g of catalyst and a reaction time of 2 h. As shown in Table 3 , the 20 %-MoO3-ZrO2 catalyst exhibits an excellent catalytic performance in the reaction with furfural, cyclopentanone, cyclohexanone, and benzaldehyde. It is interesting that the catalytic performance significantly reduces in the reaction with 4-methylfurfural, 4-methylcyclohexanone, 4-chlorobenzaldehyde, and 4-methylbenzaldehyde, probably due to the increased steric hindrance caused by the presence of different groups [53]. It is worth noting that the catalytic performance of 1-acetophenone is poor, further confirming the effect of steric hindrance on the reaction performance [54]. Therefore, the 20 %-MoO3-ZrO2 solid acid is suitable for most acetalization reactions, except for those involving compounds with steric hindrance. The textural properties and chemical bonds of 20 %-MoO3-ZrO2 catalyst after reaction were studied. The XRD pattern of the catalyst is presented in Fig. 7 a. The catalyst maintains its original t-ZrO2 crystal structure. In addition, the adsorption and desorption isotherm of the catalyst (Fig. 7b) and PSD pattern (Fig. 7c) demonstrate the presence of an H1-type hysteresis loop and a narrow PSD, indicating that the catalyst still possesses an excellent mesoporous structure. TEM image (Fig. 7g) shows stacked mesoporous structures, revealing the presence of crystal planes and diffraction rings corresponding to t-ZrO2. Element mapping further confirms that elements such as O, Zr, and Mo are evenly dispersed on the material skeleton. These results show that 20 %-MoO3-ZrO2 catalyst still maintains excellent pore size structure after recycling. The catalyst for cyclic testing was further evaluated using Raman spectrum, UV–vis spectrum and XPS (Figs. 7d, 7e, 7f, and S8) techniques. No significant change before and after the reaction is observed. Therefore, the 20 %-MoO3-ZrO2 catalyst is an excellent catalyst and has a satisfactory application prospect. Conclusion In this paper, a novel MoO3-ZrO2 solid acid catalyst with different MoO3 contents (0–30 mol%) was synthesized through a one-pot hydrothermal method. The results show that the MoO3-ZrO2 solid acid catalyst has excellent texture properties. A detailed analysis of the relationship between the existence status of Mo species and the acidity showed that the high dispersion of Mo species was conducive to improving the acidity of MoO3-ZrO2. Furthermore, both Brønsted and Lewis acid sites existed in MoO3-ZrO2, as indicated by the DFT calculations, also suggesting that the interaction between acetone and the Lewis acid sites is stronger than that of the Brønsted acid sites. The best catalytic performance in the conversion of glycerol to solketal was achieved for 20 %-MoO3-ZrO2, whose glycerol conversion and solketal selectively were 89 % and 97 %, respectively. In addition, no noticeable decline in the catalytic performance was observed even after five cycles. Therefore, the MoO3-ZrO2 material is a promising solid acid catalyst for the solvent-free acetalization of glycerol to solketal. coredata.dc:description: Glycerol acetalization to solketal is a promising method of increasing the additional value of glycerol, which is a by-product in biodiesel industry. In this work, a series of mesoporous x-MoO3-ZrO2 (x = Mo/Zr) solid acid catalysts with controllable Mo contents were designed and synthesized for the acetalization of glycerol. As important influence factors of solid acid catalysts, the mesoporous structure and existential state of Mo species were systematically investigated. Results show that Mo species were introduced as planned and existed in a homogeneously dispersed state in MoO3-ZrO2 materials. The acidic properties of MoO3-ZrO2 were explored through NH3-TPD and pyridine-chemisorbed FT-IR spectroscopy, and the formation of Brønsted and Lewis acid sites was confirmed by density functional theory calculations. Given their excellent acidity, MoO3-ZrO2 catalysts were employed for the acetal reaction of glycerol. Among the tested catalysts, the 20 %-MoO3-ZrO2 catalyst exhibited the optimal catalytic performance and reusability, achieving a conversion of 89 % for glycerol and a selectivity of 97 % for solketal. Consequently, MoO3-ZrO2 is a green solid acid catalyst with promising applications in solvent-free solketal production from glycerol.
